@allenf32 @gladstein For what it's worth, it wasn't aimed at him personally. It was used as an exemplar of a class of reaction that anybody commenting on crypto sees: anti- / maximalist reflexivity. Even where we disagree, I like Alex, find his work valuable, and wish him well.

@TheBlueMatt That came off sharply, which was unfair. Sorry. My point is "if you build it, they will come" is a lie. You have to build not only what people need, but what they want. And privacy happens to be both. Thanks again.

@TheBlueMatt I encourage you to make me look like an idiot. I will applaud you for it. Make the fixation on Lightning seem like a galaxy brain move instead of a colossal mistake by, for a start, getting the vast majority of transactions to happen there.

@TheBlueMatt ...but they're not addressing the high severity problem confronting the ordinary bitcoin users who don't even notice fancysig faffery exists (beyond eventually reduced tx sizes). The thing is, I want to be wrong. But proving me wrong doesn't happen on Twitter. It happens on-chain

@TheBlueMatt Public speaking is hard, but my intended point was not opaque: neither Taproot nor Lightning come even *close* to addressing Bitcoin's privacy problems -- and in fact even provoke arguments for how they hurt it (at least short term). That's not to say they're worthless...

@danheld @TheBlueMatt Others have shown ways to deal with this. For example, voluntary opt-out of tx privacy for those who want to show an audit trail. Turnstiles to reveal counterfeiting bugs ("has supply been increased through exploits?"), etc. Privacy doesn't demand sacrificing ancillary features.

@TheBlueMatt People have a tendency to view my criticisms are trash-canning the subject of it, but I don't want Bitcoin (or whatever) to go away: I want it to save the world. And it never will if we don't have the courage to admit where it isn't good enough.

Thanks for the thought responses.

@TheBlueMatt And again, I think Bitcoin is literally a historic achievement. It has changed public agreement of what money can be, and I use it all the time. But CBDCs are at the door, KYC abuse is everywhere, and we have very few years before the ol' empire strikes back...

@TheBlueMatt ...role is to remind that devs need not simply care, but to care enough to risk solving (what I do recognize) is a very hard problem. I get the Segwit baggage, and I understand the arguments for conservative, incremental change. But a too-late solution is no solution at all.

@TheBlueMatt I think bitcoin devs care about privacy, but caring is merely prerequisite: necessary for a solution, but not a solution in itself. I have an public obligation to advocate that bitcoin has no greater problem than privacy. Other cares more about efficiency, tps, etc, so my...
Since everybody in crypto is discussing clips from this talk today, here's the full conversation with @MartaBelcher: https://t.co/y2foTvjGlW
I'm afraid I have some bad news: https://t.co/28DQb8i1CF https://t.co/rLOH9cuwjL
A story of the government spying on journalists should not be buried on a Friday: https://t.co/bfNVCirjpl

The central property of cash is fungibility—meaning a dollar spent by a plumber is honored equally to one spent by a sex worker: they are indiscriminable. Adversarial chain analysis of Bitcoin's public ledger reduces its fungibility over time. Only privacy guarantees fungibility.

4) Privacy coins are great, but they're too small and too easy to smother via regulatory actions like de-listing from exchanges. Only Bitcoin has immunity-via-dominance to delisting. It adopting privacy-by-design instantly normalizes financial privacy. Ultima Ratio Cryptum.

3) Bitcoin's disastrous privacy is the "missing stair" of cryptocurrency. Every expert understands it's a problem, but—as experts—they themselves know how to compensate for the risk in their own personal interactions with Bitcoin, and therefore feel no urgency to actually fix it.

...despite the theoretical risk of harming the value of that ownership, I continue to criticize Bitcoin's (and other cryptocurrencies I hold) failings because the public cost of doing otherwise would be orders of magnitude greater than that individual private gain. Moral compass.

1) This is such a profoundly misleading TL;DR of a privacy-focused talk that it's hard to call it anything but intentionally deceptive.

2) To the extent I own crypto (unless and until it has been lost in boating accidents), I own more bitcoin than anything else—but

The worst part of cryptocurrency transforming into dragon-level wealth is witnessing good people emotionally devolve into dragons themselves: so intellectually paralyzed by the fear that everyone they see threatens their hoard that they lose sight of the world beyond their cave. https://t.co/GlcZ8uUw8S

I had a truly excellent conversation with the deeply impressive @MartaBelcher on cryptocurrencies, the threat of Central Bank Digital Currencies, privacy coins, Bitcoin's Taproot upgrade, how cash is tracked, and other things, like, you know, mass surveillance. Watch here: https://t.co/ozccM8dV1E
Read about it here: https://t.co/2H81IMtepC
